Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Piezoelectric Self-sensing Shoe Insole
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project lies in an ability to provide information regarding human movement in a way that is less expensive, more robust, and more accurate than existing methods, in order to improve human health and performance. The project advances several technology areas including ?smart? wearable sensors, mobile assistive technology, and multi-sensor networked decision-making. The insole launches into the rapidly growing ?wearable device? market, which is anticipated to grow by 200% over the next 3 years. The introduction of an economical self-sensing material that can transform current foam and compliant components into high-accuracy deformation sensors has huge potential in almost all fields of consumer products and engineering. Initial interest has already been expressed from manufacturers of running shoes, athletic helmets, car bumpers, airbag sensors, and mattress manufacturers. Other applications are numerous: self-monitoring artificial spine segments, self-sensing furniture, smart mounts for vibrating equipment, etc. Furthermore, the collaboration with Brigham Young University (with a specific focus on undergraduate mentoring) introduces a large number of future engineers to the works of high-tech startups, and a wide variety or ?real world? engineering issues.

This Small Business Technology Transfer Research (STTR) Phase I project will demonstrate feasibility, in terms of both technology and market, of a self-sensing piezoresponsive insole. Using novel and robust technology, the insole will quantify 3D ground reaction force characteristics during various human movements, potentially assisting an American society that is aging and overweight in becoming more healthful. Research objectives will focus on the exploitation of an entirely new class of nano-composite foam sensors to capture gait characteristics that were previously only measurable in highly controlled laboratory conditions. An insole will be created with the ability to detect all necessary components of ground reaction force, while remaining almost impervious to moisture, with a very low power requirement. The technology will be configured using wireless data transfer and smart-phone apps to provide ?smart? wearables for four specific user applications: exercise analysis, video game input, physical therapy aid, and gait biofeedback. Examples of specific objectives include accurate estimates of caloric expenditure and retraining of movement patterns that are detrimental to lower-extremity musculoskeletal health. The commercial feasibility of the insole will be validated, including a large-scale manufacturability review and market testing of the beta-stage product.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As a nation, the US population is elderly, overweight, and its joints are wearing out at unprecedented rates.  However, there is recent evidence that the public wants to improve its overall health through increased attention to health and diet.  Wearable technology for identifying type and intensity of activity, along with the associated energy expenditure is already establishing itself as a key tool in this effort.  Nevertheless, existing accelerometer-based solutions for measuring and distinguishing human activity are fundamentally limited by their underlying technology, with accuracy rates at an abysmal 60% or lower.  

This Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project demonstrated feasibility, both in terms of the technology and the market for a self-sensing piezoresponsive insole that dramatically improves accuracy rates (up to 97%).  The fundamental underlying technology is an entirely new class of piezoresponsive nanocomposite sensors that was discovered during previous NSF-funded work.  We call it “Smartfoam.”

These Smartfoam sensors leverage a triboelectric nano-effect to deliver an economic (and therefore accessible) solution for improved sensor robustness, sensitivity, and accuracy for a thriving market in the area of health monitoring wearables.  The piezoresponsive insole (Figure 1) is able to detect all 3 components of ground reaction force (3 vector directions for force as shown in Figure 2), while remaining almost impervious to moisture, with a very low power requirement (no power is required for the sensor itself), in a robust and easily adaptable mechanical form factor.  From a science and technology perspective, the project also resulted in a model for the triboelectric physics behind the quasi-piezoelectric response of the insole, exploitation of that model to refine the configuration of the piezoresponsive insoles and finally test the refined insole system, including wireless data transfer and smart-phone app, in a variety of every-day conditions: i.e., walking and running for varying distances and durations, to ensure practical usability.    

During the project, a variety of nanoparticles, ranging from carbon nanotubes to nickel nanostrands, were embedded into different elastomeric foams. By testing different material types and shapes, the underlying triboelectric nature of the self-sensing foam was verified and characterized, and optimal materials were developed for in-shoe applications. Additionally, the characteristics of the self-sensing foam were characterized in high cycle loading, as well as under representative variations in temperature and humidity.

Multiple human subjects were recruited to walk and run in a traditional motion analysis laboratory, as well as around a custom-configured outdoor 5K course. While the subjects walked and ran, ground reaction forces (GRF) that were experienced by the subjects were measured using both traditional laboratory instruments and the athletic shoes that contained self-sensing insoles. By comparing the GRF measured by the scientific instruments to the ground reaction forces measured by the self-sensing insoles, it was demonstrated that the Smartfoam can accurately measure ground reaction forces (Figure 3).   

The introduction of an economical self-sensing material that can transform current foam and compliant components into high-accuracy deformation sensors has huge potential in almost all fields of consumer products and engineering. Initial interest has already been expressed from manufacturers of running shoes, athletic helmets, car bumpers, airbag sensors, and mattress manufacturers. Other applications are numerous – self-monitoring artificial spine segments, self-sensing furniture, sensing car seats, interactive carpet for entertainment, education, and security, as well as smart mounts for vibrating equipment, etc. Nano Composite Products, Inc (NCP) was formed to commercialize Smartfoam technology and has benefitted from both private investment and this NSF grant. This grant enabled a partnership with the US Military to design Smartfoam shoe insoles that can monitor the health and activity of soldiers during training and in the field. Ultimately, they plan to use the data collected from the insoles to increase the health of soldiers while reducing injuries. Contracts are also being pursued with major mattress manufacturers and foam suppliers. Although NCP is in discussions to implement Smartfoam technology in numerous products in a variety of industries, we remain focused on Smartfoam shoe insoles. NCP welcomes any and all inquiries. If you want to learn more about this exciting technology, please visit our website at www.xonano.com.
